results.title: How the whale got his throat
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: Rudyard Kipling’s whimsical story of how the whale got his sieve-like throat is the subject of this animated film. Long ago, after the whale has eaten all the fish in the sea, he decides to consume a sailor on a raft. Once inside the whale the man jumps about, causing hiccups, until the whale agrees to take him home to get rid of him. As he leaves the whale’s mouth at the trip’s end, the sailor lodges a huge grid, made from his cut-up raft, in the whale’s throat so that until this day the whale can eat only very small fish.

results.title: How the west was lost: the story of the 1946 Aboriginal pastoral workers' strike
results.creator_credit: David Noakes, Heather Williams, Friends Film Productions and Market Street Films
results.brief_description: The story of the 1946 Aboriginal Pastoral Workers’ Strike. Eight hundred aboriginal station workers walked off sheep stations in the north west of Western Australia, marking the beginning of a strike which lasted more than three years. The strike was more than a demand for better wages and conditions, it was a struggle for basic human rights.

results.title: How the myth was made
results.creator_credit: George C. Stoney, James B. Brown and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the filming of Robert Flaherty’s film “Man of Aran”. Includes interviews with participants in the original project and raises questions about some scenes in the original film, which were of long discontinued activities re-enacted for the 1934 film. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: How the motor car works
results.brief_description: This series explains the mechanics of the motor car, a machine that has changed the world profoundly, influencing economic and social development. Areas covered on the tape include the petrol engine, the carburettor, engine lubrication and the diesel engine.

results.title: How the first letter was written
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Adapted from Rudyard Kipling’s “Just so stories” this animated film is a mythical story about the world’s first letter written by a cave girl humorously illustrating the advantages of written communication.

results.title: How television works
results.creator_credit: Colin Bell, Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and J. Arthur Rank Organisation
results.brief_description: An explanation of the basic principles of television, including the principles of the television camera in photography and in broadcasting images. Illustrates how the lens puts the picture on to the end of a special vacuum tube, how the picture is changed into electrical impulses and how electron beams spray the mosaic. The transmitting aerial and family scenes before the home television set complete the cycle of transmission.

results.title: How talkies talk
results.brief_description: How the microphone picks up sound in the film studio; how the electrical impulses are transmitted to the recording room and amplified, how sound is photographed on to a special track, how a married print is made, and how sound works when projected in a cinema.

results.title: How sugar is refined
results.brief_description: Describes how raw sugar is shipped to various refineries throughout Australia and also abroad. Shows the various stages in the manufacturing processes by which the raw product is converted into sugar fit for human consumption.

results.title: How solid is rock?
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Provides a series of investigations which will lead to an understanding of the behaviour of rock. Shows how a rapid rate of deformation in rock produces fracturing while a slow rate produces flow. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: How seeds are scattered
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Designed for primary schools, shows how plants produce flowers and then fruits which contain seeds. Different kinds of fruits and seeds - runner beans, laburnum tree, willow seeds, thistles, sycamore tree, are used to illustrate methods of dispersal by wind, water and animals.
